qas.question: What is the software that performs audio and/or video compression?
How high can compression rates go?
What is one digital network through which a digital stream can be transmitted?

answers.text: convert the digital pulses to/from analog waves

plausible_answers.text: digital compression of audio and video streams in real time

qas.question: What is the core digital network used in a videoconferencing system?
What is the low speed application that performs compression?
How high can audio modems go?

plausible_answers.text: The resulting digital stream of 1s and 0s is subdivided into labeled packets, which are then transmitted

qas.question: What is transmitted through low speed applications of some kind?

plausible_answers.text: the digital pulses to/from analog waves

qas.question: What does an ISDN convert in the audio spectrum range?

context: The core technology used in a videoconferencing system is <b5_0>digital compression of audio and video streams in real time<b5_0/>. The hardware or software that performs compression is called <a0_0><b6_0>a codec (coder/decoder)<b6_0/><a0_0/>. Compression rates of <b7_0>up to <a1_0>1:500<b7_0/><a1_0/> can be achieved. <b8_0>The resulting digital stream of 1s and 0s is subdivided into labeled packets, which are then transmitted<b8_0/> through a digital network of some kind (usually ISDN or <a2_0>IP<a2_0/>). The use of audio modems in the transmission line allow for the use of POTS, or the <a3_0>Plain Old Telephone System<a3_0/>, in some low-speed applications, such as videotelephony, because they <a4_0>convert <b9_0>the digital pulses to/from analog waves<b9_0/><a4_0/> in the audio spectrum range.
